title: alex-salmond-harassment-allegations-nicola-sturgeon-reacts
story: The First Minister issued a statement following the revelations the Mr Salmond was the subject of two complaints that were investigated by the Scottish Government.  The investigation is into two complaints of incidents alleged to have taken place at Bute House, the First Minister&rsquos official residence in 2013.  Ms Sturgeon said she agreed to the procedure covering ministers and former ministers in December 2017 but that while she was aware of the investigation she had no role in it.  Ms Sturgeon said that she was initially made aware of the investigation by Mr Salmond himself.  She said: &ldquoAlthough I have been aware for some time of the fact of the investigation &ndash initially from Alex Salmond &ndash I have had no role in the process, and to have referred to it before now would have compromised the integrity of the internal investigation, which I was not prepared to do.  &ldquoHowever, I was informed by the Permanent Secretary earlier this week that she had completed her investigation and that she intended to make the fact of the complaints public.  &ldquoAlex Salmond is now challenging the Scottish Government&rsquos procedure in court. The Scottish Government refutes his criticisms of its process and will defend its position vigorously.  &ldquoHowever, this focus on process cannot deflect from the fact that complaints were made that could not be ignored or swept under the carpet.  The First minister said here relationship with Mr Salmond, who she has previously described as a mentor, makes it difficult to deal with but that people must feel able to make complaints.  She added: &ldquoI have been clear on many occasions that all organisations and workplaces must make it possible for people to come forward to report concerns and have confidence that they will be treated seriously.  &ldquoFor that principle to mean anything it cannot be applied selectively. It must be applied without fear or favour, regardless of the identity, seniority or political allegiance of the person involved.  Mr Salmond denied the allegations and was taking action against the Scottish Government claiming he was denied the opportunity to refute them.  He said the claims which date back to 2013 were &ldquopatently ridiculous and said the investigation was &ldquounjust.

title: nicola-sturgeon-says-salmond-claims-cannot-be-swept-under-the-carpet
story: The First Minister said she had been aware of the investigation into Mr Salmond &ldquofor some time but has had no role in the process.  It comes after the Scottish Government&rsquos Permanent Secretary Leslie Evans accused the ex-first minister of &ldquosignificant inaccuracies in a statement he released last night.  Mr Salmond has been reported to police over claims of sexual misconduct against two staff members in Bute House in December 2013, when he was first minister.  Ms Evans confirmed two complaints in relation to his behaviour were received in January this year. Mr Salmond was told of the allegations in March.  The Permanent Secretary said she told Mr Salmond she intended to make the claims public on Wednesday, but this was delayed after Mr Salmond launched legal proceedings, which have now been dropped.  Mr Salmond has strongly denied wrongdoing, claiming some of the allegations are &ldquoridiculous.  Ms Sturgeon said: &ldquoComplaints were made in January relating to Alex Salmond by two individuals.  &ldquoThese complaints have been considered since then under a procedure covering ministers and former ministers that was agreed by me in December 2017 in the wake of public concern about harassment.  &ldquoAlthough I have been aware for some time of the fact of the investigation &ndash initially from Alex Salmond &ndash I have had no role in the process, and to have referred to it before now would have compromised the integrity of the internal investigation, which I was not prepared to do.  &ldquoHowever, I was informed by the Permanent Secretary earlier this week that she had completed her investigation and that she intended to make the fact of the complaints public.  &ldquoAlex Salmond is now challenging the Scottish Government&rsquos procedure in court. The Scottish Government refutes his criticisms of its process and will defend its position vigorously.  &ldquoHowever, this focus on process cannot deflect from the fact that complaints were made that could not be ignored or swept under the carpet.  &ldquoI have been clear on many occasions that all organisations and workplaces must make it possible for people to come forward to report concerns and have confidence that they will be treated seriously.  &ldquoFor that principle to mean anything it cannot be applied selectively. It must be applied without fear or favour, regardless of the identity, seniority or political allegiance of the person involved.  &ldquoMy relationship with Alex Salmond obviously makes this an extremely difficult situation for me to come to terms with. I am also acutely aware how upsetting this will be for my party.  &ldquoHowever the over-riding priority must be to ensure fair and due process. I would also ask that the privacy of those who have complained be respected.  Last night, Mr Salmond announced a judicial review of the Scottish Government&rsquos handling of the complaints process, singling out Ms Evans for criticism.  He is expected to hold a press conference later today.

title: snp-urged-to-suspend-salmond-over-misconduct-claims
story: The former First Minister has been in the party for almost 45 years.  Labour said the serious nature of the allegations against Mr Salmond meant his party should not hesitate to suspend his membership.  The Scottish Tories also said the SNP should consider suspension.  MSP Monica Lennon, Labour&rsquos equalities spokesperson, said: &ldquoGiven the serious nature of these allegations, it would be appropriate that the SNP suspend Alex Salmond's membership of the party with immediate effect.  Tory MSP Rachael Hamilton added: "We&nbspdo not yet&nbspknow the substance of the&nbspallegations facing Mr Salmond. All that can be said is that, in deeply sensitive cases like this,&nbspdue and fair process should be followed.  "The question of Mr Salmond's membership of the SNP is something his party leadership&nbspshould consider seriously in light of the&nbspfacts."  There is a recent precedent for a suspension.  The SNP suspended former childcare minister Mark McDonald last year after he resigned from the government over misconduct allegations.  The party also launched its own in-depth investigation into his conduct.  Mr Salmond has been accused of sexual misconduct by two former cicil servants in relation to alleged incidents in December 2013 at Bute House, when he was First Minister.  He has denied any wrongdoing, calling the some of the complaints &ldquoridiculous.  He has also denied any criminality.  However SNP leader and First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said the complaints could &ldquonot be ignored or swept under the carpet.  The party has so far failed to answer phone and email queries about whether it is taking action against its most famous member.

title: fringe-online-nationalists-insist-alex-salmond-claims-are-conspiracy
story: A number of so-called &ldquocybernat Twitter accounts have rushed to defend the ex-first minister from allegations of sexual misconduct.  Mr Salmond has been reported to the police over the claims, which relate to his behaviour towards two staff members in 2013.  He has strongly denied wrongdoing, claiming some of the allegations are &ldquoridiculous.  Nicola Sturgeon said the claims were &ldquoextremely difficult to come to terms with but cannot be ignored or swept under the carpet.  But on Twitter, fringe nationalists and anonymous accounts have voiced a number of conspiracy theories.  One user called Mr Malky said the &ldquoattacks on Yes Facebook pages, independence-supporting websites and blogs&hellipand Alex Salmond are not unconnected.  He added: &ldquoThe British state is terrified Scotland ends the 1707 union.  Another account, @ChrisMcCusker67, suggested the claims were intentionally leaked to newspapers to attack the independence cause.  He added: &ldquoThis stinks of #WillieMacrae &amp has MI5 written all over it.  Willie MacRae was an SNP activist and Scottish lawyer who was found shot in the head after his car crashed in the Scottish highlands in 1985.  His death was officially ruled as suicide but conspiracies and claims he was murdered have persisted to this day.  Another account, @Scotlandscreams, said the allegations against Mr Salmond were &ldquofrankly ridiculous.  It said: &ldquoBe aware the British state has no scruples and is morally bankrupt. The smear begins on the former FM Alex Salmond.  Elsewhere, @Fions18 said the media is scared of Mr Salmond and would do anything to blacken his name.  A user called Ken Reid &ndash tweeting under @1606kenreid &ndash said: &ldquoAnd tonight the guns are pointed at Alex Salmond.  &ldquoMedia speculation designed to discredit a proud Scot. My instinct is this stinks of establishment desperation to discredit a proud man.  &ldquoI so hate the MSM these days. The media fat cats have so much control it&rsquos sick.  Others suggested the allegations were part of a &ldquodirty tricks campaign by the establishment, or &ldquounionist state harassment.

title: kremlin-backed-rt-sticks-by-alex-salmond-amid-harassment-claims
story: Mr Salmond is facing allegations relating to his behaviour towards two staff members in December 2013, when he was first minister.  Nicola Sturgeon has said the claims are &ldquoextremely difficult to come to terms with but cannot be ignored or swept under the carpet.  Russian broadcaster RT, which airs the Alex Salmond Show every Thursday morning, indicated&nbspit would not be suspending him.
